Award.AwardTitle: Intrinsic and Extrinsic Factors in Rescuer Behavior

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Jennie E. Burnet of the University of Louisville will undertake research on rescuer behavior, community-level resistance to violence, and rescuer motivation during the 1994 genocide in Rwanda. The study's central question is: how and why do some people put themselves at great risk of harm in order to rescue others during communal violence? The study will compare rescuer behavior among different ethnic and religious groups in that country to identify the intrinsic factors (such as character, identity, religious belief, and religious practice) and extrinsic factors (such as geography, proximity to victims, opportunity, and community structure) that make rescuer behavior possible. The researchers will investigate the potential impact of social network characteristics on resistance to genocide and will attempt to identify aspects of faith, practice, leadership, or community structure that led to community-level resistance to genocide in certain locales.

Using social science research methods, the project will gather life history narratives, key informant interviews, testimony about the genocide, and social network data from more than 250 Rwandans in eight communities in Rwanda. A range of actors, including publicly recognized rescuers, bystanders, perpetrators, and victims will be interviewed.

This research will contribute to the scientific understanding of rescuer behavior, resistance to communal violence, and the impact of religion on these behaviors. It will also assist policymakers in developing interventions to improve resistance to communal violence. The project will contribute to basic understanding of the Rwandan religious communities and the connections between Rwandan local social movements and global religious communities. Finally, this study can offer a timely contribution to national and international policy debates about religion and violence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated rescuer behavior, community-level resistance to violence, and rescuer motivation during the 1994 genocide in Rwanda. The study's central question was: how and why do some people put themselves at great risk of harm in order to rescue others during communal violence? The study compared rescuer behavior among different ethnic and religious groups in that country to identify the intrinsic factors (such as character, identity, and religious belief), extrinsic factors (such as geography, proximity to victims, opportunity, and community structure), and sociological factors that make rescuer behavior possible. 

            Using social science research methods, the project gathered life history narratives, key informant interviews, and testimony about the genocide from approximately 230 Rwandans in eight communities in Rwanda. A range of actors, including publicly recognized rescuers, bystanders, perpetrators, and victims were interviewed.

The research discovered that acts of rescue included a range of activities: 

  • Small gestures of assistance like warning people of imminent attacks or providing food, water, clothing or other assistance
  • Hiding people.
  • Negotiating for the people?s release or the sparing of their lives.
  • Bribing genocide perpetrators with money or gifts to release people or spare their lives.
  • Hiding or protecting children. 
  • Smuggling people across the border.
  • Fighting against attackers and dying with people who were being targeted. 

            A primary finding of this study is that acts of rescue are often performed by ordinary people in the midst of the extraordinary circumstances of war, genocide, and mass violence. In the Rwandan genocide, most people?s first reaction was to help their kin, neighbors, friends, and coworkers. Over time, many people abandoned rescue efforts as the perceived risks of rescue increased, as rescue attempts failed, and as government security forces and militias adapted their tactics to defeat the compulsion to help. Rescuers, on the other hand, persisted in their sense of the moral necessity of rescue even as that choice forces them to engage in morally dubious decision-making. In fact, it is their willingness to make morally problematic decisions, such as refusing help to some while saving others, that distinguishes successful rescue from martyrdom. Rescuers improvised their actions in relation to rapidly changing circumstances.

The project identified several common factors of rescue. The compulsion to help arose from several different variables:

  • A sense of shared humanity motivated many rescuers. This sense of common humanity is a moral characteristic, grounded simultaneously in individual character or self-conception, in social ties, and in culture.
  • Overlapping social ties of kinship, religion, patron-client relations, and friendship compelled some people to help.
  • For many rescuers, the will to help was united with a strong belief that rescue was the only viable option.
  • Being asked for help significantly increases the likelihood someone will rescue

            Genocide timelines and the changing strategies of national, regional, or local government entities responsible for the genocide shaped the possibilities for rescue, their likelihood for success, and the risks of their failure. Where the genocide started early, rescue was more dangerous?and thus less likely?from the beginning of violence on April 6, 1994. In communities where the Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF) rebels advanced quickly and took control of territory, acts of rescue, including the many small gestures of assistance, were more likely to succeed and resulted in more lives being saved. 

            Geography and the built environment played a significant role in terms of what types of rescue were possible. In communities near the international border, whether over land or water, smuggling people to safety was an option. In Muslim communities that dated from the colonial period, the built environment facilitated community efforts to hide people and keep out assailants

            Prior research had demonstrated that social ties created pressure for many people to join in killing. This project found that rescuers relied on social logics to support their efforts. As the perceived risk of helping Tutsi escape rose, people engaged in rescue shifted their strategies to hide their rescue efforts in diffuse networks of helpers. 

            Religion cut across intrinsic, extrinsic, and sociological factors. For some people, their understanding of their religions? moral teachings and their belief in the goodness of God and heaven reinforced their courage to risk death to try to help people. Sometimes it created boundaries between groups that marginalized minorities, such as Muslims in Rwanda. These minority communities were often insulated from social ties that pushed people to join in the killing. 

            This research will contribute to the scientific understanding of rescuer behavior, resistance to communal violence, and the impact of religion on these behaviors. The project results can assist policymakers in developing interventions to improve resistance to communal violence. Finally, this study offers a timely contribution to national and international policy debates about religion and violence.
